Dear Mr. Culp:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 9/27/2021-
10/4/2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, MDHHS Policy, and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your MDHHS Policy. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the policy or MISEP citations
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation shall be conducted each year.
1 of 14 employee files reviewed contained a performance evaluation which was
completed outside of the required timeframe.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report
1 of 3 special evaluations reviewed was not written within 15 days of the conclusion
of the investigation completion.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days
of its completion.
1 of 3 special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation that the report
was provided to the family as the letter uploaded to the file was addressed to the
incorrect family.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child
4

(g)Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child
(h)Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
child and the foster family, including information about
siblings who do not reside in the foster home
(i) Name of assigned social service worker
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care
(2) For an emergency placement, if any of the information
specified in subrule (1)(a) to (h) of this rule is not available
at the time of placement, then the agency shall provide
information to the foster parent within 7 calendar days of
the placement.
6 of 11 open case files reviewed were missing the required Placement Outline
(DHHS-3307) and/or Medical Authorization (DHHS 3762) which documents all of the
information required per the cited rule. The missing documents were related to both
initial placements and placement changes.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
3 of 11 open case records reviewed contained 1 service plan that was not completed
within the required timeframe.

SRM 200 Personnel Training
Security Awareness Training is required to be taken within
six months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access
and every two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for
ensuring all personnel with CHRI access completes SAT
timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all employee
personnel files and/or their LMS transcripts to confirm
completion of training
1 of 8 applicable employee files reviewed contained a training record that identified
the training as having been completed outside of the required timeframe.
PA 116 722.120 Confidentiality
sec 10 (3)
A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection, records regarding children and
facts compiled about children and their parents and
relatives are confidential and disclosure of this information
shall be properly safeguarded by the child care
organization, the department, and any other entity in
possession of the information
1 of 3 special evaluations reviewed specifically identified the involvement of CPS-
MIC.
722-06B FTM Types & Timeframes
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
6

Placement Preservation/ Disruption:
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down
from a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP,
or request for change in foster home/relative placements
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven business
days of the FTM.
9 of 11 open case files reviewed did not contain documentation of the required
family team meetings. The missing meetings were related to placement changes,
service plan development, and case closure. Additionally, in some of the cases
where the required meetings were documented to have been held, the required
DHS-1105 forms were not uploaded.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/8/2020
10/14/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/7/2019

P. 25

FOM 722-08C FOSTER CARE - PARENT-AGENCY TREATMENT PLAN &
P. 4 & 9 SERVICE AGREEMENT
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker,
7

supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and
older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee.
All treatment plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or
later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.

801-01 P. 3 & 4 Dental Examination Schedule
Dental examinations are required for children one year of
age and older, as follows:
• A dental examination within three months before entry
into foster care or an initial dental examination shall be
8

completed not more than 90 calendar days after entry into a
foster care out-of-home placement.
• A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every
six months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
2 of 8 open foster care cases did not contain documentation that all dental
examinations were completed within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as R 400.12413(1)(ii))
9/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/8/2020
10/14/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/7/2019
801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
Initial Medical Passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young adult
re-entering foster care.
Updated Medical Passport
An updated medical passport is provided to:
Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
-Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
The child’s foster care provider
-At or prior to each placement.
-Quarterly.
Older youth/young adults:
-Upon initial independent living placement (youth aged 16 and
over).
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
9

7 of 11 total open case files reviewed did not contain all of the required medical
passports completed as required. The violations were related to quarterly updates,
initial placement, and placement changes.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/8/2020
10/14/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/7/2019
FOM 722-03C Life Skills Assessment & Independent Living Placement
P. 1 & 3
The Casey Life Skills Assessment must be completed
within 90 days of a youth turning 14, and annually
thereafter.
Placement in independent living may be an acceptable
living arrangement for youth 16 years or older. Prior to
placement in independent living, the caseworker must
assess the youth, with the Casey Life Skills Assessment, as
being prepared for independent living and demonstrate a
pattern of mature decision making.
2 of 3 open independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation that
Casey Life Skills assessments were completed as required.
722-06H P. 17 & CONTACT WITH SUPERVISOR (SUPERVISION)
18
The caseworker must meet with their supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every assigned case.
Exception: The caseworker must meet weekly with their
supervisor for case consultation on any case where a child
is placed in an emergency shelter facility; see Child in an
Emergency Shelter Facility in this item.
Monthly case consultations must be identified in
MiSACWIS with the case contact type of supervision.
1 of 11 open case files reviewed did not contain documentation that monthly
supervision occurred for the month of January of 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/14/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/8/2020
10/14/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/7/2019
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
10

 When endorsing reports for the purpose of borrowing beds, ensure that each
endorsing signature is dated.
 The intake date of a special evaluation must match the date the information of
a potential rule non-compliance is received by the agency.
 All supervision meetings must be documented within the appropriate case’s
social work contacts.
 If placements are created in error the MiSACWIS help desk must be
contacted to assist in correcting the error.
 All contacts, including foster home visits, must be entered within the
timeframe outlined in the applicable policy.
 All signatures must be dated with the date the signature is actually completed,
not backdated to reflect the date the form was completed or the action.
documented on the form took place as backdating is considered falsification
of documentation.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Review of the processes currently in place to ensure compliance should be
completed to understand where the process is falling short to identify if
changes to the process need to be made or if individual staff need additional
training and/or support.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
9/14/2020 RENEWAL inspection report, CAP approved 10/8/2020. The facility is not
in compliance with CAP based on the number of repeat violations cited during this
inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The Chief Administrator Assessment was
reviewed and discussed during the entrance. While the assessment did identify
some areas of non-compliance there appeared to be a lack of awareness of the
breadth of non-compliance within the identified areas.
Interviews – The staff members interviewed reported feeling supported by their co-
workers and superiors. They reported the use of checklists and other mechanisms
developed after last year’s inspection to improve compliance.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
11

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on
a regular license.
